content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Domenic: one thing I noticed with `review.py` is that it didn't reuse the existing origin branch when doing the update. It's not too hard to correct later as git push will tell you what to do, but it would be nice if it sorted that automatically. Would you happen to know offhand what we need to change? Otherwise I can look into it.

Maybe pass `--set-upstream-to=X`?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Domenic: one thing I noticed with review.py is that it didn't reuse the existing origin branch when doing the update. It's not too hard to correct later as git push will tell you what to do, but it would be nice if it sorted that automatically. Would you happen to know offhand what we need to change? Otherwise I can look into it.
Maybe pass --set-upstream-to=X?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> Domenic: one thing I noticed with `review.py` is that it didn't reuse the existing origin branch when doing the update. It's not too hard to correct later as git push will tell you what to do, but it would be nice if it sorted that automatically. Would you happen to know offhand what we need to change? Otherwise I can look into it.

Maybe pass `--set-upstream-to=X`?

In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
Domenic: one thing I noticed with review.py is that it didn't reuse the existing origin branch when doing the update. It's not too hard to correct later as git push will tell you what to do, but it would be nice if it sorted that automatically. Would you happen to know offhand what we need to change? Otherwise I can look into it.
Maybe pass --set-upstream-to=X?

content.body: The interop 2023 proposal for history & navigation is live: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/170
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The interop 2023 proposal for history & navigation is live: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop/issues/170

content.body: Is there anything in modern specs that strips usernames/passwords from URLs before fetching? Apparently we do this in at least one place in Chromium and I'm trying to figure out why...
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Is there anything in modern specs that strips usernames/passwords from URLs before fetching? Apparently we do this in at least one place in Chromium and I'm trying to figure out why...

content.body:
> <@domenicdenicola:matrix.org> Is there anything in modern specs that strips usernames/passwords from URLs before fetching? Apparently we do this in at least one place in Chromium and I'm trying to figure out why...

Not an answer, but found https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=82250. But that also doesn't provide any clarity about why or what spec the behavior might be based on
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @domenicdenicola:matrix.org
Is there anything in modern specs that strips usernames/passwords from URLs before fetching? Apparently we do this in at least one place in Chromium and I'm trying to figure out why...
Not an answer, but found https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=82250. But that also doesn't provide any clarity about why or what spec the behavior might be based on

content.body: And found https://twitter.com/mikewest/status/846308572124397569
https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/465
Domenic: are those relevant or do you mean in some other context?
content.formatted_body: Domenic: are those relevant or do you mean in some other context?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: are those relevant or do you mean in some other context?
Domenic: are those relevant or do you mean in some other context?

content.body: These are helpful, but the code we actually have seems to strip out the URL credentials, instead of blocking the request entirely... https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/fetch_parameters.cc;l=94;drc=a432cd59d51281057ba2a2673ca645a9600bb927 . I can't find any evidence of this in specs.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: These are helpful, but the code we actually have seems to strip out the URL credentials, instead of blocking the request entirely... https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/loader/fetch/fetch_parameters.cc;l=94;drc=a432cd59d51281057ba2a2673ca645a9600bb927 . I can't find any evidence of this in specs.

content.body: It seems like we do this somewhat randomly... for various cross-origin images, prefetches, preloads, modules, stylesheets??
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It seems like we do this somewhat randomly... for various cross-origin images, prefetches, preloads, modules, stylesheets??

content.body: I guess I'll comment on the PR 465
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I guess I'll comment on the PR 465

content.body: Commented with what I suspect is the cause
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Commented with what I suspect is the cause

content.body: Do you know what the rationale is behind which fetches set use-URL-credentials and which don't?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Do you know what the rationale is behind which fetches set use-URL-credentials and which don't?

content.body: Domenic: for CORS and new APIs we wanted to avoid it
content.formatted_body: Domenic: for CORS and new APIs we wanted to avoid it

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: for CORS and new APIs we wanted to avoid it
Domenic: for CORS and new APIs we wanted to avoid it

content.body: Domenic: stripping could work too btw, but have to be careful with redirects and service workers
content.formatted_body: Domenic: stripping could work too btw, but have to be careful with redirects and service workers

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: stripping could work too btw, but have to be careful with redirects and service workers
Domenic: stripping could work too btw, but have to be careful with redirects and service workers

content.body:
> If there’s an authentication entry for httpRequest and either httpRequest’s use-URL-credentials flag is unset or httpRequest’s current URL does not include credentials, then set authorizationValue to authentication entry. 

This is not great, "authentication entry" is a concept but I think it's saying to extract the credentials from the URL... Will file an editorial issue I guess.
content.formatted_body:
If there’s an authentication entry for httpRequest and either httpRequest’s use-URL-credentials flag is unset or httpRequest’s current URL does not include credentials, then set authorizationValue to authentication entry.

This is not great, "authentication entry" is a concept but I think it's saying to extract the credentials from the URL... Will file an editorial issue I guess.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
> If there’s an authentication entry for httpRequest and either httpRequest’s use-URL-credentials flag is unset or httpRequest’s current URL does not include credentials, then set authorizationValue to authentication entry. 

This is not great, "authentication entry" is a concept but I think it's saying to extract the credentials from the URL... Will file an editorial issue I guess.

If there’s an authentication entry for httpRequest and either httpRequest’s use-URL-credentials flag is unset or httpRequest’s current URL does not include credentials, then set authorizationValue to authentication entry.

This is not great, "authentication entry" is a concept but I think it's saying to extract the credentials from the URL... Will file an editorial issue I guess.

content.body: Domenic: well an authentication entry is the user agent having authorization data for some URL, but if there's also credentials in the URL itself those might override that
content.formatted_body: Domenic: well an authentication entry is the user agent having authorization data for some URL, but if there's also credentials in the URL itself those might override that

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: well an authentication entry is the user agent having authorization data for some URL, but if there's also credentials in the URL itself those might override that
Domenic: well an authentication entry is the user agent having authorization data for some URL, but if there's also credentials in the URL itself those might override that

content.body: Domenic: those used to be the semantics, but I'm not really sure what has happened in the intervening years as there's been a bunch of interventions with poor cross-browser coordination
content.formatted_body: Domenic: those used to be the semantics, but I'm not really sure what has happened in the intervening years as there's been a bunch of interventions with poor cross-browser coordination

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Domenic: those used to be the semantics, but I'm not really sure what has happened in the intervening years as there's been a bunch of interventions with poor cross-browser coordination
Domenic: those used to be the semantics, but I'm not really sure what has happened in the intervening years as there's been a bunch of interventions with poor cross-browser coordination

content.body: Yeah I mean I'd at least expect this to say "the authentication entry for the URL", ideally with an algorithm detailing how to extract the username/password components from the URL itself.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yeah I mean I'd at least expect this to say "the authentication entry for the URL", ideally with an algorithm detailing how to extract the username/password components from the URL itself.

content.body: OK, two issues and a PR later, I think I'm done shaving this yak...
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: OK, two issues and a PR later, I think I'm done shaving this yak...

content.body: speaking of yak shaving… let me present https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8338
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: speaking of yak shaving… let me present https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/8338

content.body:
PR-preview rendered output at https://whatpr.org/html/8338/syntax.html#start-tags (step 6)

> Then, if the element is one of the void elements, or if the element is a foreign element, then there may be a single U+002F SOLIDUS character (/), which on foreign elements marks the start tag as self-closing **but on void elements does not mark the start tag as self-closing but instead is unnecessary and has no effect of any kind and should be used only with caution — especially since, if directly preceded by an unquoted attribute value, it becomes part of the attribute value rather than being discarded by the parser.**

content.body:
would there be a use case for this.

such as, no we do not want to let you put your login and password in there, but the request is going through and the site will send you an authentification challenge instead for this URL so you can log in more securely instead of just failing.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text:
would there be a use case for this.

such as, no we do not want to let you put your login and password in there, but the request is going through and the site will send you an authentification challenge instead for this URL so you can log in more securely instead of just failing.
